title: Control of Documents and Records
description: Systematic control of documents and records to ensure current, accurate, secure, and accessible documentation throughout the facility

requirements.text: Is there a written document control procedure (including document control register/record) describing how documents will be maintained, updated and replaced?
mandatoryStatements: Written document control procedure exists
Procedure describes document creation, review, and approval process
Document control register/record tracks all controlled documents
Procedure defines how documents are updated and replaced
Version control and effective date management are specified
Procedure identifies who is authorized to create and approve documents
Process for removing obsolete documents is defined
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual audit of document control procedure and register for completeness and compliance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Quarterly review of document control register, immediate verification during document updates

requirements.text: Is there a documented and implemented procedure that requires all records to be stored for a minimum period of 24 months (or greater if legally required) or for at least the shelf life of the product if it is greater than 24 months?
mandatoryStatements: Record retention procedure is documented
Minimum retention period of 24 months is specified
Longer retention for products with shelf life exceeding 24 months
Legal and regulatory retention requirements are identified and met
Procedure defines record disposal process after retention period
Different record types and their specific retention requirements are identified
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual audit of record retention compliance, verification that records meet minimum retention periods
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Quarterly check of record storage and retention, annual disposal of expired records per procedure

requirements.text: Are both paper and electronic food safety related documents and records created, edited, stored and handled in a secure manner?
mandatoryStatements: Paper documents are stored in secure, controlled-access locations
Electronic documents are password-protected or access-controlled
Backup systems exist for electronic records
Only authorized personnel can create, edit, or delete documents
Audit trails track changes to electronic documents
Physical security measures protect paper records from damage, loss, or unauthorized access
Environmental controls protect records from deterioration
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual security audit of document and record storage systems, quarterly verification of backup systems
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly verification of access controls, immediate backup after critical record creation

requirements.text: Are records maintained in an organized and retrievable manner?
mandatoryStatements: Records are organized using logical filing system (chronological, categorical, or alphanumeric)
Filing system is documented and understood by relevant personnel
Records can be retrieved quickly for audits or investigations
Index or catalog system helps locate specific records
Both paper and electronic records are systematically organized
Organization method supports traceability requirements
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual verification of record organization system effectiveness, quarterly spot-checks of record retrieval
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly review of filing system compliance, immediate organization of new records upon creation

requirements.text: Are all records and test results that can have an impact on the food safety program verified by a qualified person independent of the individual(s) completing the records?
mandatoryStatements: Food safety-related records are verified by qualified personnel
Verifier is independent of the person who created the record
Verification includes review of completeness, accuracy, and compliance
Test results are reviewed by technically qualified personnel
Verification is documented (signature, date, or electronic approval)
Frequency of verification is defined based on risk
Non-conformances identified during verification trigger corrective action
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual audit of record verification system, quarterly sampling of records to confirm independent verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily or weekly verification of critical food safety records, immediate verification of out-of-specification test results

capaInject: If document control procedure not followed: immediate correction of non-compliant documents, retraining within 7 days
If records not retained per procedure: investigate cause, recover records if possible, implement controls to prevent recurrence
If unauthorized access to documents/records detected: immediate password reset, investigate breach, implement enhanced security within 30 days
If records not retrievable: conduct immediate search, implement improved organization system within 14 days
If record verification not performed: immediate verification of all affected records, retraining of responsible personnel
traceabilityInject: Document control register must trace all document versions and revision history
Records must be traceable to specific dates, personnel, and activities
Electronic document audit trails must trace all changes, editors, and approval history
Record verification must be traceable to specific verifiers and verification dates
